net.sf.clickclick.jquery
Class Taconite

java.lang.Object
  net.sf.clickclick.util.Partial
      net.sf.clickclick.jquery.Taconite

public class Taconite
extends net.sf.clickclick.util.Partial

Provides a Java API for the JQuery Taconite plugin: http://www.malsup.com/jquery/taconite.

Taconite allows you to perform multiple DOM updates for a single Ajax request. Taconite produces an XML document consisting of commands that is executed in order by the browser.

Common usages include: updating Controls, adding new Controls, removing Controls, replace content of Controls and even executing raw JavaScript code.

The API consists of two classes: Taconite and Command although in most cases you will only use the Taconite class.

This API provides a number of pre-defined commands for example: REPLACE, REPLACE_CONTENT, AFTER, EVAL. Do note that you are not limited to the predefined commands and can use any other JQuery functions available, even your own custom defined functions.

Example usage

The example below demonstrates how to replace the content of a Span target with today's Date. A Taconite command "replaceContent" is used to replace the content of the Span. 
 public MyPage extends Page {

     private JQActionLink link = new JQActionLink("update", "Update Text", "updateId");
     private Span span = new Span("span", "spanId");

     public void onInit() {

         addControl(link);
         addControl(span);

         link.setActionListener(new AjaxAdapter() {

             // Implement the onAjaxAction method which receives Ajax requests
             public Partial onAjaxAction(Control source) {
                 // Note Taconite is a Partial subclass
                 Taconite partial = new Taconite();

                 // Using a CSS selector to replace the Span content with the latest
                 // Date
                 partial.replaceContent(span, "Updated at " + new Date());

                 return partial;
             }
         });
     }
 }

Multiple Commands

You can add an unlimited amount of commands to the Taconite instance. For example: 
 public MyPage extends Page {

     ...

     public void onInit() {

         link.setActionListener(new AjaxAdapter() {

             // Implement the onAjaxAction method which receives Ajax requests
             public Partial onAjaxAction(Control source) {
                 // Note Taconite is a Partial subclass
                 Taconite partial = new Taconite();

                 // Using a CSS selector to replace the Span content with the latest
                 // Date
                 partial.replaceContent(span, "Updated at " + new Date());

                 // Add a Form after the span
                 partial.after(span, form);

                 // Add a Table after the Form
                 partial.after(form, table);

                 return partial;
             }
         });
     }
 }
The commands are executed one after the other in the order they were added. Note the last two Commands above where first the Form is added and then the Table is added after the Form. This works because the Form has been added by the time the Table is added.

Please note: because Click Pages are stateless by default, any Controls added to the Page via Ajax will be removed when the Page is refreshed. It is therefore recommended to consider stateful Pages when working with highly dynamic Pages.

Creating custom commands

It is very easy to create your own custom commands. See custom commands for more details.

JavaScript and CSS resource handling

Taconite uses the JavaScript, "/clickclick/jquery/jquery.click.js", to enable smooth integration with Apache Click.

The "jquery.click.js" library includes the following JQuery plugins:

  1. JQuery Taconite - provides ability to execute a list of commands in the browser
  2. JQuery LiveQuery - allows JavaScript events (onclick, onblur etc) that are bound on Controls to persist even if the underlying Control is replaced by an Ajax request. The latest versions of JQuery supports the new "live()" functionality which is similar to LiveQuery, but it does not support all events yet.
  3. Click specific functionality - to allow a Control's resource dependencies (JavaScript and CSS) to be added through Ajax requests.
Its worth discussing how Control resources (JavaScript and CSS) are handled by Taconite.

Firstly, Taconite ensures that all duplicate JavaScript and CSS resoures are removed before returning the response. For example if you return two DateFields, Taconite will ensure that only one set of JavaScript and CSS resources are returned. Duplicate resources are identified as follows:

  • JsImport and CssImport are unique based on their attributes "src" and "href" respectively.
  • JsScript and CssStyle are unique based on their "ID" attribute. Note, if the ID attribute is not set Taconite won't be able to determine if the resource is a duplicate or not.
Secondly, all JavaScript and CSS resources returned to the browser are checked whether they should be added to the Page or not. The identification procedure is the same as above:
  • if a JsImport or CssImport is already part of the Page, it is not added again.
  • if a JsScript or CssStyle has an ID attribute defined, the Page is checked for Script and Style elements with the same ID. If an existing element is found the Script or Style is not added to the Page. Note, sometimes it is desirable to execute a Script regardless if it has executed before. In those situations simply ignore the ID attribute.

Author:
Bob Schellink

Constructor Detail

Taconite

public Taconite()
Create a default Taconite instance.

Please note, the Partial.setContentType(java.lang.String) is automatically set to Partial.XML since Taconite returns an XML document.

Please note, the Partial.setContentType(java.lang.String) is automatically set to Partial.XML since Taconite returns an XML document.

addHeader

public Command addHeader(org.apache.click.element.Element element)
Create an ADD_HEADER command for the given Element and add it to the list of commands.

If the Element is an instance of JsImport, CssImport or CssStyle it will be added to the Page HEAD (<head>).

If the given Element is an instance of JsScript it will be evaluated instead.

Parameters:
element - the Element to add
Returns:
the command that was created

addHeader

public Command addHeader(java.util.List<org.apache.click.element.Element> elements)
Create an ADD_HEADER command for the given list of Elements and add it to the list of commands.

If an Element in the list is an instance of JsImport, CssImport or CssStyle it will be added to the Page HEAD (<head>).

If an Element in the list is an instance of JsScript it will be evaluated instead.

Parameters:
elements - the list of Elements to add
Returns:
the command that was created

after

public Command after(java.lang.String selector,
                     java.lang.String content)
Create an AFTER command for the given CSS selector and content and add it to the list of commands.

The given content will be added after the element/s targeted by the CSS selector.

Parameters:
selector - the CSS selector e.g: '#myId' or '.myClass'.
content - the content to add after the element/s targeted by the CSS selector
Returns:
the command that was created

Create a PREPEND command for the given CSS selector and content and add it to the list of commands.

The given content will be prepended to the element/s targeted by the CSS selector.

Parameters:
selector - the CSS selector e.g: '#myId' or '.myClass'.
content - the content to prepend to the element/s targeted by the CSS selector
Returns:
the command that was created

processHeadElements

protected void processHeadElements()
Process the HEAD elements of Controls contained within Taconite commands. This method will recursively process Containers and all child controls.

All non JsScript HEAD elements will be added to a new Command which is set as the first command in Taconite. This ensures that HEAD elements are present in the Page before any DOM content is added.

All JsScript HEAD elements will be added to a new Command which is set as the last command in Taconite. This ensures that JavaScript snippets are executed after the DOM content is available. If JsScript elements was not added after DOM content you would run into situations where JavaScript code would reference DOM elements which have not been added to the DOM yet.
